David VillalÃ³n, the CEO and co-founder of Spanish AI startup Maisa, exemplified this blend of excitement and alarm. â€œThis massive investment shows that the next stage in the growth of AI â€” Artificial Superintelligence â€” is no longer a fringe concept but an inevitable reality requiring unprecedented investment in infrastructure, akin to laying down the tracks for the next Industrial Revolution,â€ he said. html:
Donald Trumpâ€™s big AI announcement has turned heads on both sides of the Atlantic.

Trump revealed this week that OpenAI, SoftBank, and Oracle have formed a joint venture â€” called Stargate â€” that will invest $500bn in AI infrastructure. The companies said $100bn of the funding was available immediately. The rest would be deployed over the next four years.

Trump billed Stargate as â€œthe largest AI infrastructure project by far in history.â€ He added that the project would ensure â€œthe future of technologyâ€ is in the US.

Masayoshi Son, the CEO of SoftBank, had another bold prediction. He said the venture would driveÂ  â€œartificial superintelligence.â€

The ğŸ’œ of EU tech

The latest rumblings from the EU tech scene, a story from our wise ol' founder Boris, and some questionable AI art. It's free, every week, in your inbox. Sign up now!

European tech leaders echoed the sentiment â€” but fear that the continent will become beholden to American power.

David VillalÃ³n, the CEO and co-founder of Spanish AI startup Maisa, exemplified this blend of excitement and alarm.

â€œThis massive investment shows that the next stage in the growth of AI â€” Artificial Superintelligence â€” is no longer a fringe concept but an inevitable reality requiring unprecedented investment in infrastructure, akin to laying down the tracks for the next Industrial Revolution,â€ he said.

VillalÃ³n added that the transition requires powerful new computing capacity. Stargate will bring a big dose of this to the US. European tech leaders have called for the continent to react

â€œWithout large-scale capital commitments and a bold approach to AI infrastructure, Europe risks surrendering its future to global players who control the fuel of tomorrow,â€ VillalÃ³n said.

Europeâ€™s AI worries

VillalÃ³n pointed to the example of his home country. He believes Spain has â€œimmense potentialâ€ in renewables, but needs a major funding boost to remain globally competitive and strategically independent.

â€œSpain is spending peanuts on vacuous publicity AI projects, while ignoring, or not understanding, whatâ€™s needed â€” compute,â€ he said.

Similar anxieties have reverberated across Europe. Jan Marquardt, the CEO of German startup Zivee, warned that AI companies need strong infrastructure, big funding, and minimal regulation, â€œall of which is available in the USA â€” and not in Europe.â€ Christian Klein, the CEO of German tech SAP, added that Stargate should be â€œa wake-up callâ€ for the continent.

VillalÃ³n shares their concerns.

â€œTo use a football analogy, Europe is currently in the relegation zone while USA and China â€” with their budgets, quality and ambition â€” are operating in the Champions League,â€ he said.
